title: 109_s2475
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community Act of 2006". It establishes a commission. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community consists of 23 members appointed by various officials. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community consists of 23 members appointed by various officials. The minority leader of the House of Representatives, the majority leader of the Senate, and the minority leader of the Senate each appoint 3 voting members. Additionally, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, the minority leader of the House of Representatives, the majority leader of the Senate, and the minority leader of the Senate each appoint 1 nonvoting member. Members must have a demonstrated commitment to research, study, or related fields. Members of the Commission must have a commitment to the research, study, or promotion of American Latino life, art, history, political or economic status, or culture. They should also have expertise in museum administration, fundraising for nonprofit or cultural institutions, or teaching Latino culture and history at the postsecondary level. The Commission members should have expertise in fundraising for nonprofit or cultural institutions, teaching Latino culture and history at the postsecondary level, studying the issue of Smithsonian Institution's representation of American Latino art, life, history, and culture, or experience in public or elected service. Additionally, they should have experience in museum administration or planning for the establishment of museums focused on ethnic, racial, or cultural groups. Additionally, they should have experience in museum administration or planning for the establishment of museums focused on ethnic, racial, or cultural groups. SEC. 3. FUNCTIONS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress with recommendations for establishing and maintaining a National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC. They will develop fundraising plans for the Museum and examine issues in consultation with the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress on issues related to the National Museum of the American Latino Community, including the availability and cost of collections, impact on regional museums, and possible locations in Washington, DC. The Commission will submit a report on Latino-related museums, including possible locations in Washington, DC, governance structure, community engagement, and legislation to carry out the plan of action. The Commission will submit a report on Latino-related museums, including possible locations in Washington, DC, governance structure, community engagement, and legislation for consideration by relevant House and Senate committees. The Commission will convene a national conference on the Museum, involving individuals dedicated to promoting American Latino life, art, history, and culture, within 9 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS. The Secretary of the Interior provides administrative services, facilities, and funds for the Commission's functions. Commission members not employed by the government receive compensation and travel expenses as determined by the Secretary of the Interior. The Commission must submit final reports, plans, and recommendations within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting these documents. $2.1 million is authorized for fiscal year 2007 and $1.1 million for fiscal year 2008 to support the Commission's activities.
